newsitem.title: FRANCE: EU official visits Paris to plead farm reform.
newsitem.headline: EU official visits Paris to plead farm reform.

text.p: The European Union's senior agricultural civil servant visited Paris on Tuesday for talks with the government on proposed sweeping farm reforms which French farmers have vowed to resist.

French officials said Guy Legras, director-general for agriculture at the EU's executive Commission, met European Affairs Minister Pierre Moscovici to present the fine print of the EU's Agenda 2000 plan announced in Brussels this month.

France's Socialist-led government, elected in June, has already urged the Commission to make serious changes to the plan, which would cut guaranteed prices to help the 15-nation EU prepare for expansion towards former East Bloc countries.

France believes the price cuts would be a sign of weakness ahead of further liberalising trade negotiations with the United States due in 1999. But on a previous visit to Paris two weeks ago, Legras said EU negotiators would be helped not hindered by arriving at those talks with domestic reforms already under way.
No further details were immediately released on Tuesday's meeting, held at the French Foreign Ministry.

French farm unions, who staged massive protests against previous reforms in 1992, when the last Socialist government was in office, have called the new price cuts "unacceptable" and pledged a campaign against them.
